I've been thinking of doing a story where initially things are nonconsensual/reluctant on the woman's part at first. Problem is I can't really settle on a situation. I'm just not sure how rape-y things should be to begin with. Here's a couple scenarios I'm thinking of:
>Political marriage between a human and a noble anthro woman. She despises the union, but she's forced to go through with it and give up her virginity to him in front of a watching crowd. While she hates him and the marriage at first though they eventually begin to for a bond
>A young man is given an anthro slave girl as a gift for his 18th birthday, and is pressured by his father to take her virginity. After doing so she continues on as his personal attendant, while the two start to enjoy one another's company more and more
>An older anthro widow is blackmailed into fucking by one of her son's human friends, who found her and her deceased husband's old sex tapes. Of course she hates it at first, but when he starts talking about taking the relationship seriously she finds herself having mixed emotions.
I guess the wall I'm hitting is, how far is too far in a situation like this? The scenarios I have set up means no guy gets cucked because I generally don't like that, but is that a deal breaker for a lot of you? If the guy's kind of a scumbag early on does that leave any potential ending ringing hollow? What if multiple anthro women get involved?

Anonymous Sat 26 Sep 2020 12:09:49 No.33035501 Report
Quoted By: >>33035953
>>33035112
Any setting comes with its pros and cons. Sci-fi can explain a lot of things through technology, and if all you want is waifurs created by science, then that's frankly enough. To really take advance of the genre, though, you'd have to focus on the exploration of alien planets, space anomalies, or dive into the ethical questions of meeting other species and how to deal with the inevitable culture clashes. That's the stuff that really makes the genre fun. Oh, and potential human evolution through science, social order and, to a lesser degree, spirituality

Personally I find a lot of sci-fi boring when it's little more than an excuse to blow shit up in space

Anonymous Sat 26 Sep 2020 12:20:27 No.33035620 Report
Quoted By: >>33035953 >>33037230 >>33037725 >>33038677
>>33035112
Hard sci fi is one of my top jams. Doesn't matter if it's anthro or aliens or whatever. I mean, like Frank Herbert & David Brin & C.J. Cherryh & Philip Jose Farmer & Ursula Le Guin & Asimov & Larry Niven & etc. Bring it. Let's see some uplift and genetic engineering and cloning and space cats having zero-G sex and social interactions on colony ships taking a couple decades to get to their new planet ... imagine it and bring it.

Be able to clone yourself, spliced with animal DNA and genetically engineered for your new planet's environment, then upload your consciousness into the clone, explore your new body type with all your shipmates and the options they chose for different niches. A world full of proto-anthros/pseudo-humans, filling ecological niches as effectively new species. Yet they retain enough compatibility for crazy sex, family units, relationships, and have to solve genetic incompatibilities for breeding purposes.

Is there gonna be war? Need a warrior caste? Is this gonna be Start Trek with furries? Or more like The Fifth Element? Is this gonna be frontier exploration? Science research mission? All sorts of crazy shit to delve into. What ch'ya got in mind?

But, make it HARD sci fi, to the best of your ability. Not interested in sparkle-magic hand-wavium ponies being best friends in space magical girl shit "because" love and faith are superior to technology.

>>33035501
Well, I agree. That's one of the reasons I'm actually into SF. And why I'm an asshole who says SF instead of sci-fi. One idea that keeps recurring in all the various, poorly defined settings that pop up into my head is a setting with different "species" that are created through the proliferation of mankind across the stars, possibly with one claiming or being seen as "human" while they would seem like another departure from human to us. Possibly with a main character who's a relict, a human much like us.

>>33035620
>>33035742
Not gonna lie. I do like space cats. But I've already been doing cats a lot. I was contemplating maybe doing not cats. As for what you mention about the setting and such, I've kind of answered that up top. I do think you propose an interesting avenue, because a lot of mainstream stuff treating this sticks to some artificial hard border when it comes to body modification. Like, people always go nuts when they're not in their birth body or whatever. That always seemed weird to me.

Anyway, in regards to hard SF I've always been of two minds. Star Trek is one of my favorite things ever, and it's pretty clear Star Trek is just ready to pull whatever out of its ass to make its story work. And sometimes that's exactly what they need. On the other hand, there's literally no point to doing space stories if you're not willing to treat space, and everything in it, with a modicum of respect. Yes, I get very annoyed when something claiming to be SF has its spaceships burning towards their destination on approach.

I'd have to have more of a big think about what's going to be happening. Right now I have spaceships, weird worlds, and big furry asses in space. Possibly big furry cat asses.

Anonymous Sat 26 Sep 2020 14:59:52 No.33037345 Report
Quoted By: >>33037586
>>33037071
One of the primary decision you're going to make that sets a huge part of the tone: who has access to hyper-light speed transportation? The characters in the story may not have access to it, or a limited form tat still takes years between star systems. There may have once been a known tech that could take you 100 light years in a few hours, but it's lost to the protagonists. Maybe legends that it is still in use by some people or aliens somewhere, but out of reach at least at the beginning of the story.

A built-in time delay in star travel (let alone inter-galactic) can accomplish a more "real world" feel to a science fiction setting. People have to struggle somewhat for star travel, it's a big deal that consumes wealth & resources and has to be intricately planned around.

Previously in universe, some form of hypertravel may have been available. But that civilization has collapsed and teh tech is lost now. Or something happened to the universe itself that broke it. Maybe a critical resource got used up and is too rare to support that form.

Your mention of an AI singularity is intriguing. Suppose 50,000 years ago there was an AI singularity and there was convenient hypertravel where you could cover 1000 light years in a day. They seeded out the galaxy with humanoid stock tailored to different planets. Maybe they could see hypertravel breaking and set up a vast reservoir of genetic potential around the galaxy so that at least some of it would survive, on its own, and one day begin to explore, colonize, and get back in touch with its long-lost cousins. And they are various anthro forms with surprising genetic and form compatibility.

The discovery of these connections is part of the story & revealed gradually, as well as the mystery of why & how all these "cousins" exist allover the place. There will also be scorched planets where this experiment failed. Maybe some can be colonized or rehabilitated/terraformed & reclaimed, maybe some are hopeless.

Anonymous Sat 26 Sep 2020 15:07:37 No.33037422 Report
Quoted By: >>33037524
>>33037262
As far as I'm aware the original definition is that it should be technologically possible. So, something like The Martian would be peak hard SF. So the nature of the genre is that writing it is almost immediately also deviating from the mission brief. Many hard SF snobs already consider anything with FTL to be soft SF, because it's simply not possible even in theory, at present. They'd no doubt think the same of human-animal hybrids. Sexy, sexy human-animal hybrids.

The way I see it, the veracity of a story is helped along immensely by an author who knows what they're writing about. Say you're writing space combat. What makes it special? Is it just two ships dogfighting WWII style? Then why the space setting? And I guarantee you, that person also knows very little of WWII dogfighting, because one of the most important components in that is energy. That is, using gravity for acceleration. Energy preservation is one of THE most important parts of a prop plane dogfight. But if someone is away of the nature of lightspeed, that's a lot more fun.

>>33037230
David Brin. The Earthclan book, which is two novels also published independently, Startide Rising and The Uplift War. The concept of uplift is critical, and he explores it over the course of about a half dozen novels. In a nutshell, species recognize lower animal forms as having potential to become advanced, sapients. They indenture & mentor them and genetically design them over the course of 10,000 to 50,000 years until they become galactic citizens themselves. In effect, it's a furry universe, but if ten thousand alien species were independently creating their versions of anthros.

If those two grab your interest, there is a trilogy in the same universe, and it's some brilliant, hard SF.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uplift_Universe

But, Brin has written a lot, and some of his other work is also incredible, intricate and detailed. If Frank Herbert had been a physicist instead of a sociologist. Brin is a genius level intellect and very rewarding in his SF efforts (usually ... there are some failures).

Anonymous Sat 26 Sep 2020 15:16:02 No.33037524 Report

>>33036803
>pretensions of proper world-building
I personally feel that half the time you have to know exactly how & why a certain bit works or you end up applying our logic to somewhere it doesn't fit.
The other half, you throw the pasta at the wall and figure out later how not make that retcon one of the biggest asspull plot points. That's just overcompensation for the "It makes sense to them", and when a bad writing team hits that there's little hope of a fix.

>>33037262
I personally use a sliding scale.
A certain chunk of fantasy falls under the partial shadow of hard sci-fi. The reader is given the understanding on how the world works, and all the foreshadowing lines up.
Something I'm working on takes a harder tack. I have a more than casual knowledge of legit pharmacy and organic chem, so I wrote up a few ideas on the how & why in that dry journal format. I don't think anyone but a neuropharmacy PhD would pick up on any errors from what will make it into the text, but it's possible.
My hangup is hard sci-fi is usually taken to me hard physics, full stop. When it isn't, the next redoubt is chemistry. Your normal engineering post-grad should have the same appreciation for mathematical approximations as a soldier has for the business end of a gun, but forget number crunching isn't the real world.

>>33037422
Veracity is part of it, but knowing what not to say allows the harder reader to not have that break of disbelief while still keeping the less educated reader involved.

Anonymous Sat 26 Sep 2020 15:22:11 No.33037586 Report
Quoted By:
>>33037345
If I want the main characters to travel to fun weird worlds, then by necessity there will have to be accessible FTL travel. It's also more conducive to a developed universe, in my opinion. And if you want the characters to develop and maintain relationships with other characters who aren't on their ship, then people either need to be long-lived, or the FTL travel in question needs to be relatively fast. I'd consider this to be mainly a narrative concern. One thing to consider might be different types of FTL travel that do different things and can be used with various levels of ease. Another idea I like, which is relatively common in science fiction, is the existence of "core worlds" versus various backwaters, with corresponding differences in technology. That can play well into the availability of FTL tech. Also, I consider the idea of Space African flying around in Space Technicals funny.

The seeder intelligence (whatever form it takes) would, first and foremost, be a narrative conceit on my part. They can neatly explain why humanity was spread across the stars in such a diaspora manner, it can also explain weird genetic deviations, and even the weird worlds people find themselves on. And, of course, it provides a strong historical focal point for the people in the setting. But mostly it allows you to do stuff as a writer. Why are there space cats with giant butts? Well, the seeder intelligence gave them giant butts.

It's an idea I thought was pretty neat when I read it in that Stross novel. He just didn't really do much with it. Hence, it's been stuck in my mind since.

C.J. Cherryh, you'll want to read her cats in space books:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Chanur_novels

She's also the grandmother of modern science fiction in many ways. Most of her books will turn your head inside out.
Wave without a shore
40,000 in Gehenna
Voyager in Night
Serpent's reach
Hunter of Worlds
the Cyteen series

Frank Herbert, all six of his original Dune novels together are a masterwork. You really miss out if you can't make it to the end, and I agree it's not easy.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Herbert_bibliography
some highlights:
The Dosadi Experiment
The Jesus Incident
Under Pressure (originally The Dragon in the Sea)
The Santaroga Barrier
The Godmakers
The Green Brain (it's really better than that title sounds)

Ursula Le Guin, incredibly prolific, and hard to read. You have to really take your time and wrap your head around every page of her stories.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ursula_K._Le_Guin_bibliography
The Lathe of Heaven
The Left Hand of Darkness
The Dispossessed
The Word for "World" is Forest

NOT her Earthsea stuff; it's "fantasy" and ... not for everyone.

Philip Jose Farmer is wild, like Spider Robinson. You'll start to feel like your on an acid trip when you get deep into their stuff.

Larry Niven, rollicking adventures with Asimov-style science and intrigue:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larry_Niven_bibliography
Protector
Ringworld and The Ringword Engineers
Lucider's Hammer
Footfall
The Mote In God's Eye
The Magic Goes Away
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larry_Niven_bibliography

i personally define hard sci-fi as one foot in the realm of possibility and reality, with the other foot in "future technology" magic. It also has to obey a clear set of rules, no deus ex machinas here!
Star Trek TOS would be a good example of hard sci-fi. Warp drives and transporters are fantastical, but they follow a clear set of rules.
Space Battleship Yamato, however, is a great example of soft sci-fi. A goofy show that dosen't take itself too seriously, and the ship can do whatever the plot requires for that episode

Anonymous Sat 26 Sep 2020 16:06:16 No.33038139 Report
Quoted By:
>>33037262
As you can see by the other replies, "hard sci fi" is a definition that's has a very wide variety of opinion. It keeps a lot of people awake at night.

In a sense, how "hard" it is is dependent on the individual who is creating a story. How smart are they to begin with, but how educated they are on all the topics they must write about. The author needs to know when hey can't bullshit their way through a topic or subject and write around it. It's a talent to know when to be vague yet compose a plot around a subject in such a way it doesn't require a detailed explanation ... just enough to be plausible and not contradict the rest of the world building.

"Hard" in a sense is the ability to world build in such a way that all the rules of that world/universe are self-supporting. You don't get any contradicting "rules" of how things work. You don't ave to be a genius level physics professor, just understand when to shut up and not be a Dunning-Kruger idiot out loud.

I don't know how faster that light travel works, but I can write a story where it is solved, and I can set up rules how it works. Is it instantaneous? Frank Herbert in Dune used Guild Navigators who fold space and you are instantly between locations anywhere in the galaxy. Star Trek uses warp drive, with different levels of warp for different speed, and an upper limit ... which is then broken by trans-warp. And, how the fuck do ten civilizations casually use trans warp, but the Federation somehow hasn't deconstructed a Borg cube and adopted trans warp? Or stolen it from someone else? THAT is NOT "hard" sci fi.

That's why I suggested thinking heavily on interstellar travel rules for your universe early on. Why I suggested there may be different technologies and why some may or may not be available or work at all in the present day of the story. It's pretty fucking huge, and one of the biggest FAILs in most science fiction.

Internal self-consistency is "hard" science fiction.
Anonymous
  • Post
  • Report

Anonymous Sat 26 Sep 2020 16:07:14 No.33038153 Report
Quoted By: >>33038370 >>33039606
>>33037996
Here's the hard truth: The whole humanoid aliens is because of a hard limit on the nature of filmmaking. Everyone is played by actors, and it's generally considered better by pretty much everyone involved, including the audience, to leave their faces mostly free. Because it's literally part of their job. You kind of see this in Deep Space 9. When they realized Jeffrey Combs was a good actor, they specifically made the character of Weyoun for him so he could have more of his face free, and thus show more of his range. Alternatively, René Auberjonois requested more make-up for his character, Odo, because he felt it was better if the character came across as stiffer.

Of course, there are exceptions, but they're fairly rare. Specifically because this is a hard thing to do. And it will probably remain in the realm of animation for the immediate future. Though, that said, animation is a near perfect medium for a science fiction series, and it's bullshit that we still have this stigma about animation being for kids. Netflix's Death, Love, and Robots was pretty cool, and one of the very few forays of Western animation into the adult realm, despite its edgy title.

Reminds me of an argument I had recently. Someone makes a similar point, and then someone responds with the usual cherry picking of some random shitty movie, one that was never popular, from the past. I look up the corresponding year in cinema. Lo and behold, it's a year in which multiple classics were released, as well as movies that were simply good or a big thing when they were released.

As for the second part, it's not spines or gumption. It's money and expertise. The last time someone with a camcorder and some friends could make a movie and be taken seriously was The Blair Witch Project, and that was already a massive outlier making sly use of the nascent internet. It did spawn something of a genre that could be cheaply replicated, but what happened? Hollywood took it over and ran it into the ground.

The days of Italians with camcorders changing the world of cinema are long gone.

Anonymous Sun 27 Sep 2020 08:31:50 No.33054957 Report
Quoted By: >>33055130 >>33055509
>>33051556
>>33052707
>Actually, working for a living means I can barely write anything

I feel this. Working has slowed me down, but at least I'm not working full time.

As for setting stuff, I find artificial gravity to be one of those things that's hardest to handwave because of the knock-on effect it would have. If you can finetune the gravity per deck, that means you have very strong gravity control technology to the point where it ought to dominate the setting. The only setting I can offhand think of that takes this into account is Schlock Mercenary (in fact, it's one of the few things that makes it worth reading). In that setting gravity fields are an integral part of warfare, and they really would be once you get to the point of using it so frivolously to increase crew comfort. You'd use it for propulsion, offense, and defense. Even if you somehow had better stuff to do those jobs, you'd always have it on standby. It would be one of the most important technologies in the setting.

Basically, to excuse artificial gravity, you'd have to write a lot about gravity. And maybe it's just easier to go "haha, hollow drum/1g acceleration go brrrr".

Anonymous Sun 27 Sep 2020 08:51:39 No.33055130 Report
Quoted By: >>33055213 >>33055509
>>33054957
>artificial gravity
Thank you for not being retarded about this. It's one of the things that absolutely ruins a vast swath of science fiction. Almost nobody takes into account microgravity environments. Even when you have artificial gravity of sorts, the utterly casual assumption of it is cringe, page after page after page.

Say that (somehow) you manage to have gravity generators on a decent sized ship (say, crew of over 30 or 50 or so). By what sort of magic does it then exist in something the size of a two- or six-person shuttlecraft? The size of such generators and the power consumption have to consume twice teh space of a shuttle that's barely taller than a standing human and maybe three or four times as long.

And one thousand other retardations. Just because movies are shot in 1 G Earth in a studio lot. No fucking effort to ever explain or discuss or account for in 99% of all books ever written, let alone no movies or TV shows.

And, on the topic of acceleration. Never a mention of turning a passenger into a red paste any & every time a space ship comes to a "dead stop" in 1 meter, or accelerates from one planet to another to arrive within a few minutes. No fucking gravity generator is going to keep you vertical to the floor when the ship just applied 50,000 gravities toward its rear so you can make your dinner engagement on Jupiter Station.

Well, at least gravity generators are also one of the best ways of handwaving the effects of acceleration. That is, if their response time and output is in pace with acceleration. With Star Trek, in my head canon both the inertial dampeners and impulse power are gravity based.

Space war! It's something we have no real life experience with, and we can only speculate with our current understanding of the universe. One of my favorites cones from the "Forever War" book, in which the long voyages between deployments are a major world building and plot point.
As for an hmofa format, I'd say that a space faring humanity is at war with some anthro race, and a commander is trying to outsmart the other. All one side needs is a good hit at a radiator, and the enemy will be at thier mercy to be taken prisoner, or fall with thier casket of a vessel.
But the long, dreary, and hostile war is taking a toll.

Anonymous Sun 27 Sep 2020 12:45:00 No.33056864 Report
Quoted By:
>>33056446
>>33056741
Maybe try this variant. Given the FTL talk upthread, consider not having it at all. A story set within one system. It could be ours and be Earth/Sol Terran based, or invent a fantasy system, maybe even with humans.

Anyway, going with a system populated with humans, consider it in a Cowboy Bebop sort of model. There is travel inside the solar system with tech that makes it not too time consuming. There are stations around other planets and moons, some moons/asteroids have been terraformed or are in process.

Whatever dominant species (let's assume humans), they have genetically modified various animals with enough potential to advance beyond sentience into full sapience, even matching human levels. Some aspects may even exceed.

Initially, these modifications (uplift in the Brin vernacular) were for workers with specialized abilities in space and space stations as well as alien environments on various moons & planets. However, humans being human, they've lost full control. Species are trying to break out of "slavery" as many see it, some making their own gene mods. Human factions have formed. War breaks out.

Various factions are conducting terrorism, hot wars, civil wars, cold wars throughout the solar system. Some humans have been gene-modded for specialties, even combat specialties. Space monkey marines are fucking terrifying. So have various anthros, some equally terrifying. Some anthro factions have splintered off into some levels of independence, mixed with some humans and other anthro species. Some factions want to be "pure" human or other species. There are a couple dozen major factions, plus chaos and criminal & underground elements.

Our story (stories?) takes place against this backdrop. Rumors abound, there may have been an FTL breakthrough at one of the major scientific research stations, and everyone wants a piece of that action to escape the chaos of the home system, leave and found their own Utopia/Zootopia.

Anonymous Sun 27 Sep 2020 13:47:08 No.33057352 Report
Quoted By:
>>33039520
Seconding PBS Spacetime/ knowing what you're addressing. I write my science fiction semi-hard: basically anything that is possible now or has had a theoretical mechanism described. I make sure I know from a world building perspective how any given piece of technology is meant to work, but in the end I usually don't pay that information much lip service to that sort of thing in the actual text of the story.

If you want your world to feel real, then internal consistency rather than justifiability is the big thing to shoot for. Avoid technobable, especially when using real terms. Everything should mean something. That is my biggest complaint with star trek.
Anonymous
